message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change of the following reduction reaction if the standard enthalpy of formation of FeO is -272.0 kJ/mol and that of Fe is 0 kJ/mol.

FeO(s) + H2(g) → Fe(s) + H2O(l)
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change of the reaction, we need to use the following equation:

ΔH° = Σ ΔHf°(products) - Σ ΔHf°(reactants)

where ΔH° is the standard enthalpy change of the reaction, and ΔHf° is the standard enthalpy of formation of the respective substances.

We are given the standard enthalpy of formation of FeO (-272.0 kJ/mol) and Fe (0 kJ/mol). We also need the standard enthalpy of formation of H2O(l), which is -285.8 kJ/mol, and H2(g), which is 0 kJ/mol.

Now we can plug these values into the equation:

ΔH° = [ΔHf°(Fe) + ΔHf°(H2O)] - [ΔHf°(FeO) + ΔHf°(H2)]
ΔH° = [(0 kJ/mol) + (-285.8 kJ/mol)] - [(-272.0 kJ/mol) + (0 kJ/mol)]

ΔH° = -285.8 kJ/mol + 272.0 kJ/mol
ΔH° = -13.8 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change of the reduction reaction is -13.8 kJ/mol.
